description: From Middle English verdit, from Anglo-Norman verdit (> Medieval Latin veredictum), from veir (“true”) + dit (“saying”); possibly a calque of a Germanic term such as Old English sōþword, sōþsprǣċ, sōþspell, sōþsagu, or sōþcwide, all meaning "true story, statement of truth, account, history".

entries.meaning: (law) A decision on an issue of fact in a civil or criminal case or an inquest.
examples: The jury returned a “not guilty” verdict.
a “not out” verdict from the umpire
